channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Meghan and Harry interview: Tabloid racism 'large part' of why we left UK, says duke
item.description: The Duke of Sussex says the "bigoted" UK media created a "toxic environment" in newly aired footage.

item.title: Anne Sacoolas: Harry Dunn suspect 'willing to do community service'
item.description: The lawyer for Anne Sacoolas also says her client is willing to meet the teenager's family.

item.title: Covid-19: Nightingale hospitals to close from April
item.description: The temporary hospitals, which were largely unused, are being shut as patient numbers fall.

item.title: Ministers 'must quickly ban LGBT+ conversion therapy'
item.description: The government says it is "committed" to ending the practice, but campaigners want action quickly.

item.title: Bafta Film Awards 2021: Stars await nominations amid diversity push
item.description: The organisation has introduced changes after an outcry over its all-white acting line-up last year.

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: Covid in Scotland: Restrictions on outdoor meetings to be eased
item.description: Nicola Sturgeon is expected to announce a limited easing of some lockdown restrictions at Holyrood.

item.title: Child abuse laws to be expanded in England and Wales
item.description: It would put sports coaches and faith leaders on par with roles like teachers and social workers.

item.title: Zoom founder Eric Yuan transfers $6bn of his shares
item.description: His personal wealth soared as the video conferencing platform became a household name during the pandemic.

item.title: Aboriginal Australians: Victoria to hold inquiry into impact of colonisation
item.description: In a national first, Victoria will examine injustices against Aboriginal people since British settlement.

item.title: Samuel Paty: French schoolgirl admits lying about murdered teacher
item.description: The student admits she was not in class when Samuel Paty showed cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad.

item.title: UK businesses caught buying five-star Google reviews
item.description: Consumer group Which? staged a sting operation to investigate fake Google reviews in the UK.

item.title: The papers: Palace 'reeling' over Meghan and Harry 'bombshell'
item.description: Most front pages report on the fallout from Meghan and Prince Harry's interview with Oprah Winfrey.

item.title: Coronavirus: Divers find Philippine reef covered with single-use face masks
item.description: Divers in the Philippines find personal protective equipment (PPE) among rubbish on a coral reef.

item.title: The secret New York apartment behind my bathroom mirror
item.description: New Yorker Samantha Hartsoe's TikTok of her discovery of a secret flat was a viral sensation.

item.title: Video diary shows Nottinghamshire triplets' return to school
item.description: A mum of triplets films a video diary of their return to school.

item.title: Meghan and Harry interview: Racism claims, duke 'let down' by dad, and duchess on Kate
item.description: The explosive interview saw the couple talk about their relationships with other royals and racism.

item.title: Somerset starlings stop man's car in 'impressive' display
item.description: Ecologist Jamie Kingscott took a photograph of thousands of starlings as they surrounded his car.

item.title: Meghan and Harry interview: 'Royalty is not a shield from the despair of racism'
item.description: Black women in the US respond to Meghan Markle's revelations about racism and Britain.

item.title: Covid: Banksy to auction Southampton hospital artwork for NHS
item.description: The piece depicts a young boy discarding his superhero toys in favour of a model of an NHS nurse.

item.title: UK lockdown: 'Bored' landlady makes miniature version of own pub
item.description: Amy Sayers makes a tiny replica of The Swan pub in Addingham as a lockdown project "out of boredom".

item.title: Analysis: Harry and Meghan rattle monarchy's gilded cage
item.description: The couple's interview lays bare the contradictions of the royals' public and private lives.

item.title: Back to school: How pupils feel about returning to class
item.description: The BBC speaks to pupils to discover how they feel as they go back to school.

item.title: Covid: How to deal with lockdown social anxiety
item.description: Lockdown easing has lead to excitement, but anxiety for some about how to deal with normal life.

item.title: Should local council power be 'turbo-charged'?
item.description: As we await a report from government on devolution, the debate on where power should lie grows louder.

item.title: Nigeria kidnappings: The Chibok captive who defied Boko Haram
item.description: Naomi Adamu was abducted by Islamist militants from Chibok, Nigeria, in 2014 and spent three years in captivity.

item.title: Sweden leads way in using tech to boost rural retailing
item.description: In Sweden shops with no staff are popular in rural locations that have lost their local shops.

item.title: Meghan and Harry's Oprah interview: Princess Diana's significance
item.description: Prince Harry spoke about fears of "history repeating itself" when comparing his wife and his mum.

item.title: Afghanistan: Will America's 'moonshot' peace plan work?
item.description: American officials have a new draft peace deal, but Afghans worry it could make the violence worse.

item.title: Tyler Perry: The US mogul who gave Meghan and Harry a home
item.description: Tyler Perry provided the couple with a mansion and security when they moved from Canada in 2020.

item.title: Florence Price: Forgotten work by pioneering composer rediscovered
item.description: Florence Price was the first African-American woman to have a symphony performed by a top orchestra.

item.title: The woman with HIV helping others have a 'good death'
item.description: In the country with the world's highest prevalence of HIV, Thembi Nkambule doesn't want people to die of Aids ashamed and alone.

item.title: West Ham a 'special place to be' - Rice after win over Leeds takes Hammers fifth
item.description: Midfielder Declan Rice says there is a "real buzz" about West Ham after victory over Leeds maintains their push for a Champions League place.

item.title: Derek McInnes: Aberdeen part with manager after eight years
item.description: Derek McInnes, the Scottish Premiership's longest serving manager, leaves Aberdeen after eight years in charge at Pittodrie.

item.title: Chelsea 2-0 Everton: Thomas Tuchel praises Kai Havertz as Blues strengthen top-four hopes
item.description: Chelsea manager Thomas Tuchel praises forward Kai Havertz after he plays a vital role as the Blues defeat top-four rivals Everton.

item.title: 'I dread using public toilets' - rugby player Fisher on life with alopecia
item.description: Team GB rugby player Heather Fisher says she "dreads" using public toilets as she is frequently mistaken for a man because of her alopecia.

item.title: New 36-team Champions League format could be agreed this month
item.description: Plans for a reformed 36-team Champions League which would start in 2024 could be agreed by the end of this month.

item.title: Prize money 'significantly levelled up' between women's and men's sport
item.description: More sports than ever are offering equal prize money, a BBC study shows on International Women's Day.

item.title: WSL game of the season? Ebony Salmon hits winner as Bristol City beat Reading
item.description: Watch highlights as Bristol City move off the foot of the Women's Super League as Ebony Salmon scored the winner in a thrilling encounter with Reading.

item.title: Coronavirus testing: How to do a lateral flow test at home
item.description: Coronavirus lateral flow tests are free and provide a quick result within 30 minutes. But how do you do one?

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: England has entered the first stage of its lockdown easing with millions of children back at school.

item.title: Covid: Can you catch the virus outside?
item.description: The risks of catching Covid indoors are well-known, but what are the chances of being infected outdoors?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the care home visiting rules in England?
item.description: New guidance gives hope to relatives wanting to visit care homes.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: As the UK cautiously unlocks, experts will review the evidence on when and where masks are needed.

item.title: Covid: What are the new rules for schools?
item.description: All students in England can now return to classrooms, but how will Covid testing work?

item.title: How could children make up for lost school time?
item.description: A massive task lies ahead for schools as they try to make up for teaching time lost during the pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus, schools and children - what are the risks?
item.description: How much do children contribute to the spread of Covid?

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: 'I've been listening to 300 vinyl records to get me through lockdown'
item.description: Listening to all her records took Anna Doble back to her youth - releasing memories and emotions.
